The **Imperial Territory of Alsace-Lorraine** ([German](/wiki/German_language
"German language"): _Reichsland Elsaß-Lothringen_ or _Elsass-Lothringen_ ,
[French](/wiki/French_language "French language"): _Terre d 'Empire d'Alsace-
Lorraine_ or _Alsace-Moselle_) was a territory created by the [German
Empire](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire") in 1871, after it annexed most of
[Alsace](/wiki/Alsace "Alsace") and the [Moselle](/wiki/Moselle_\(department\)
"Moselle \(department\)") department of [Lorraine](/wiki/Lorraine_\(region\)
"Lorraine \(region\)") following its victory in the [Franco-Prussian
War](/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War "Franco-Prussian War"). The Alsatian part lay
in the Rhine Valley on the west bank of the [Rhine River](/wiki/Rhine_River
"Rhine River") and east of the [Vosges Mountains](/wiki/Vosges_Mountains
"Vosges Mountains"). The Lorraine section was in the upper [Moselle
valley](/wiki/Moselle_valley "Moselle valley") to the north of the Vosges.

The territory was made up of 93% of [Alsace](/wiki/Alsace "Alsace") and 26% of
[Lorraine](/wiki/Lorraine_\(region\) "Lorraine \(region\)"); the remaining
portions of these regions continued to be part of France. For historical
reasons, specific legal dispositions are still applied in the territory in the
form of a "[local law](/wiki/Local_law_in_Alsace-Moselle "Local law in Alsace-
Moselle")". In relation to its special legal status, since its reversion to
France following [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), the territory
has been referred to administratively as **Alsace-Moselle**.[note 1]

Since 2016, the historical territory is now part of the [French administrative
region](/wiki/Regions_of_France "Regions of France") of [Grand
Est](/wiki/Grand_Est "Grand Est").

## Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-Lorraine&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Geography")]

Alsace-Lorraine had a land area of 14,496 km2 (5,597 sq mi). Its capital was
[Straßburg](/wiki/Strasbourg "Strasbourg"). It was divided in three districts
(_Bezirke_ in German):

  * [Oberelsass](/wiki/Oberelsass "Oberelsass") (Upper Alsace), whose capital was [Kolmar](/wiki/Colmar "Colmar"), had a land area of 3,525 km2 and corresponds exactly to the current [department](/wiki/D%C3%A9partement_of_France "Département of France") of [Haut-Rhin](/wiki/Haut-Rhin "Haut-Rhin")
  * [Unterelsass](/wiki/Unterelsass "Unterelsass"), (Lower Alsace), whose capital was [Straßburg](/wiki/Strasbourg "Strasbourg"), had a land area of 4,755 km2 and corresponds exactly to the current department of [Bas-Rhin](/wiki/Bas-Rhin "Bas-Rhin")
  * [Lothringen](/wiki/Bezirk_Lothringen "Bezirk Lothringen"), (Lorraine), whose capital was [Metz](/wiki/Metz "Metz"), had a land area of 6,216 km2 and corresponds exactly to the current department of [Moselle (department)](/wiki/Moselle_\(department\) "Moselle \(department\)")

### Towns and cities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-
Lorraine&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Towns and cities")]

The largest urban areas in Alsace-Lorraine at the 1910 census were:

  * [Straßburg](/wiki/Strasbourg "Strasbourg") (now _Strasbourg_): 220,883 inhabitants
  * [Mülhausen](/wiki/Mulhouse "Mulhouse") (_Mulhouse_): 128,190 inhabitants
  * [Metz](/wiki/Metz "Metz"): 102,787 inhabitants
  * [Diedenhofen](/wiki/Thionville "Thionville") (_Thionville_): 69,693 inhabitants
  * [Colmar](/wiki/Colmar "Colmar") (also historically _Kolmar_): 44,942 inhabitants

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-Lorraine&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: History")]

### Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-Lorraine&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Background")]

Main articles: [French–German enmity](/wiki/French%E2%80%93German_enmity
"French–German enmity") and [Causes of the Franco-Prussian
War](/wiki/Causes_of_the_Franco-Prussian_War "Causes of the Franco-Prussian
War")

The modern history of Alsace-Lorraine was largely influenced by the rivalry
between [French](/wiki/French_nationalism "French nationalism") and [German
nationalism](/wiki/German_nationalism "German nationalism").

France long sought to attain and preserve its "[natural
boundaries](/wiki/Natural_borders_of_France "Natural borders of France")",
which are the [Pyrenees](/wiki/Pyrenees "Pyrenees") to the southwest, the
[Alps](/wiki/Alps "Alps") to the southeast, and the [Rhine
River](/wiki/Rhine_River "Rhine River") to the northeast. These strategic
claims led to the annexation of territories located west of the Rhine river in
the [Holy Roman Empire of the German
Nation](/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire#Baroque_period "Holy Roman Empire"). What is
now known as Alsace was progressively conquered by [Louis
XIV](/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France "Louis XIV of France") in the 17th century,
while Lorraine was incorporated in the 18th century under [Louis
XV](/wiki/Louis_XV_of_France "Louis XV of France").[1]

German nationalism, which resurfaced following the [French occupation of
Germany](/wiki/French_period "French period") under
[Napoleon](/wiki/Napol%C3%A9on_Bonaparte "Napoléon Bonaparte"), sought to
unify all the [German-speaking populations](/wiki/German-speaking_Europe
"German-speaking Europe") of the former [Holy Roman Empire of the German
Nation](/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire#Name "Holy Roman Empire") into a single
[nation-state](/wiki/Nation-state "Nation-state"). As various [German
dialects](/wiki/German_dialects "German dialects") were spoken by most of the
population of Alsace and [Moselle](/wiki/Moselle_\(department\) "Moselle
\(department\)") (northern Lorraine), these regions were viewed by German
nationalists to be rightfully part of hoped-for united Germany in the future.

> _We Germans who know Germany and France know better what is good for the
> Alsatians than the unfortunates themselves. In the perversion of their
> French life they have no exact idea of what concerns Germany._
>
> — [Heinrich von Treitschke](/wiki/Heinrich_von_Treitschke "Heinrich von
> Treitschke"), German historian, 1871[2][3]

The loss of Alsace and Lorraine personified – statue in

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/1887_Bettanier_Der_Schwarze_Fleck_anagoria.JPG/220px-1887_Bettanier_Der_Schwarze_Fleck_anagoria.JPG)](/wiki/File:1887_Bettanier_Der_Schwarze_Fleck_anagoria.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:1887_Bettanier_Der_Schwarze_Fleck_anagoria.JPG "Enlarge")

"The Black Stain": In France, children were taught in school not to forget the
lost provinces, which were coloured in black on maps. Painting by [Albert
Bettannier](/wiki/Albert_Bettannier "Albert Bettannier"), a native of
[Metz](/wiki/Metz "Metz") who fled to Paris after the annexation of his
hometown.

In 1871, the newly created German Empire's demand for Alsace from France after
its victory in the [Franco-Prussian War](/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War "Franco-
Prussian War") was not simply a [punitive](/wiki/Punitive "Punitive") measure.
The transfer was controversial even among the Germans: The [German
Chancellor](/wiki/Chancellor_of_Germany_\(German_Reich\) "Chancellor of
Germany \(German Reich\)"), [Otto von Bismarck](/wiki/Otto_von_Bismarck "Otto
von Bismarck"), was initially opposed to it, as he thought it would engender
permanent French enmity toward Germany. [4] Some German industrialists did not
want the competition from Alsatian industries, such as the cloth makers who
would be exposed to competition from the sizeable industry in Mulhouse. [Karl
Marx](/wiki/Karl_Marx "Karl Marx") also warned his fellow Germans: "If Alsace
and Lorraine are taken, then France will later make war on Germany in
conjunction with Russia. It is unnecessary to go into the unholy
consequences." [5]

However, the [German Emperor](/wiki/German_Emperor "German Emperor"), [Wilhelm
I](/wiki/Wilhelm_I,_German_Emperor "Wilhelm I, German Emperor"), eventually
sided with army commander [Helmuth von
Moltke](/wiki/Helmuth_von_Moltke_the_Elder "Helmuth von Moltke the Elder"),
other Prussian generals and other officials who argued that a westward shift
in the French border was necessary for strategic military and ethnographic
reasons. From an ethnic perspective, the transfer involved people who for the
most part spoke [Alemannic German](/wiki/Alemannic_German "Alemannic German")
dialects. From a military perspective, by early 1870s standards, shifting the
frontier away from the [Rhine](/wiki/Rhine "Rhine") would give the Germans a
strategic buffer against feared future French attacks. Due to the annexation,
the Germans gained control of the fortifications of [Metz](/wiki/Metz "Metz"),
though it was a French-speaking town; of [Strasbourg](/wiki/Strasbourg
"Strasbourg") (Straßburg) on the left bank of the Rhine; and of most of the
iron resources of Lorraine.

However, domestic politics in the new Reich may have been decisive. Although
it was effectively led by Prussia, the new German Empire was a decentralized
federal state. The new arrangement left many senior Prussian generals with
serious misgivings about leading diverse military forces to guard a prewar
frontier that, except for the northernmost section, was part of two other
states of the new Empire – [Baden](/wiki/Baden "Baden") and
[Bavaria](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bavaria "Kingdom of Bavaria"). As recently as the
1866 [Austro-Prussian War](/wiki/Austro-Prussian_War "Austro-Prussian War"),
these states had been Prussia's enemies. In the new Empire's constitution,
both states, but especially Bavaria, had been given concessions with regard to
local autonomy, including partial control of their military forces. For this
reason, the Prussian [General Staff](/wiki/General_Staff "General Staff")
argued that it was necessary for the Reich's frontier with France to be under
direct Prussian control.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Creating a new Imperial Territory
(_Reichsland_) out of formerly French territory would achieve this goal:
although a Reichsland would not be part of the Kingdom of Prussia, being
governed directly from Berlin it would be under Prusso-German control. Thus,
by annexing Alsace-Lorraine, Berlin was able to avoid complications with Baden
and Bavaria on such matters as new fortifications.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Memories of the [Napoleonic Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic Wars")
were still quite fresh in the 1870s. Right up until the Franco-Prussian War,
the French had maintained a long-standing desire to establish their entire
eastern frontier on the Rhine, and thus they were viewed by most 19th century
Germans as an aggressive people. In the years before 1870, it is arguable that
the Germans feared the French more than the French feared the Germans. Many
Germans at the time thought that the creation of the new Empire in itself
would be enough to earn [permanent French
enmity](/wiki/French%E2%80%93German_enmity "French–German enmity"), and thus
desired a defensible border with their old enemy. Any additional enmity that
would be earned from territorial concessions was downplayed as marginal and
insignificant in the overall scheme of things.

The annexed area consisted of the northern part of Lorraine, along with
[Alsace](/wiki/Alsace "Alsace"). The area around the town of
[Belfort](/wiki/Belfort "Belfort") (now the French _département_ of
[Territoire de Belfort](/wiki/Territoire_de_Belfort "Territoire de Belfort"))
was unaffected, because Belfort had been [defended](/wiki/Siege_of_Belfort
"Siege of Belfort") by [Colonel Denfert-
Rochereau](/wiki/Pierre_Philippe_Denfert-Rochereau "Pierre Philippe Denfert-
Rochereau"), who surrendered only after receiving orders from Paris, and was
compensated by another territory. The town of
[Montbéliard](/wiki/Montb%C3%A9liard "Montbéliard") and its surrounding area
to the south of Belfort, which have been part of the [Doubs
department](/wiki/Doubs_\(d%C3%A9partement\) "Doubs \(département\)") since
1816, and therefore were not considered part of Alsace, were not included,
although they were a Protestant enclave, as it belonged to
[Württemberg](/wiki/W%C3%BCrttemberg "Württemberg") from 1397 to 1806. This
area corresponded to the French _[départements](/wiki/D%C3%A9partement
"Département")_ of [Bas-Rhin](/wiki/Bas-Rhin "Bas-Rhin") (in its entirety),
[Haut-Rhin](/wiki/Haut-Rhin "Haut-Rhin") (except the area of Belfort and
Montbéliard), and a small area in the northeast of the [Vosges
département](/wiki/Vosges_d%C3%A9partement "Vosges département"), all of which
made up Alsace, and the _départements_ of [Moselle](/wiki/Moselle "Moselle")
(four-fifths of it) and the northeast of [Meurthe](/wiki/Meurthe_Department
"Meurthe Department") (one-third of Meurthe), which were the eastern part of
Lorraine.

The rest of the département of Meurthe was joined with the westernmost part of
Moselle which had escaped German annexation to form the new département of
[Meurthe-et-Moselle](/wiki/Meurthe-et-Moselle "Meurthe-et-Moselle").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Gare_de_Metz_R01.jpg/220px-
Gare_de_Metz_R01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gare_de_Metz_R01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gare_de_Metz_R01.jpg "Enlarge")

The neo-Romanesque Metz railway station, built in 1908. Kaiser [Wilhelm
II](/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor "Wilhelm II, German Emperor") instigated
the construction of various buildings in Alsace-Lorraine supposedly
representative of German architecture.

The new border between France and Germany mainly followed the geolinguistic
divide between French and German dialects, except in a few valleys of the
Alsatian side of the [Vosges mountains](/wiki/Vosges_mountains "Vosges
mountains"), the city of [Metz](/wiki/Metz "Metz") and its region and in the
area of [Château-Salins](/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau-Salins "Château-Salins") (formerly
in the Meurthe _département_), which were annexed by Germany although most
people there spoke French.[note 2] In 1900, 11.6% of the population of Alsace-
Lorraine spoke French as their first language (11.0% in 1905, 10.9% in 1910).

That small francophone areas were affected, was used in France to denounce the
new border as hypocrisy, since Germany had justified the annexation on
linguistic grounds. However, the German administration was tolerant of the use
of the French language, and French was permitted as an official language and
school language in those areas where it was spoken by a majority. This would
only change with the First World War in 1914.

The [Treaty of Frankfurt](/wiki/Treaty_of_Frankfurt_\(1871\) "Treaty of
Frankfurt \(1871\)") gave the residents of the region until October 1, 1872 to
choose between emigrating to France or remaining in the region and having
their nationality legally changed to German. About 161,000 people, i.e.,
around 10.4% of the residents of Alsace-Lorraine, opted for French citizenship
(the so-called _Optanden_); however, only about 50,000 actually emigrated,
while the rest acquired German citizenship.[6]

The sentiment of attachment to France stayed strong at least during the first
16 years of the annexation. During the Reichstag elections, the 15 deputies of
1874, 1881, 1884 (but one) and 1887 were called _protester deputies_ (fr:
_députés protestataires_) because they expressed to the
[Reichstag](/wiki/Reichstag_\(German_Empire\) "Reichstag \(German Empire\)")
their opposition to the annexation by means of the _1874 motion_ in the French
language: « May it please the Reichstag to decide that the populations of
Alsace-Lorraine that were annexed, without having been consulted, to the
German Reich by the treaty of Frankfurt have to come out particularly about
this annexation. »[7] The Saverne Affair (usually known in English-language
accounts as the [Zabern Affair](/wiki/Zabern_Affair "Zabern Affair")), in
which abusive and oppressive behaviour by the military towards the population
of the town of Saverne led to protests not just in Alsace but in other
regions, put a severe strain on the relationship between the people of Alsace-
Lorraine and the rest of the German Empire.

Under the German Empire of 1871-1918, the annexed territory constituted the
_Reichsland_ or Imperial Territory of _Elsaß-Lothringen_ (German for Alsace-
Lorraine). The area was administered directly from Berlin, but was granted
limited autonomy in 1911. This included its constitution and state assembly,
its own flag, and the _[Elsässisches
Fahnenlied](/wiki/Els%C3%A4ssisches_Fahnenlied "Elsässisches Fahnenlied")_
(_Alsatian Flag Song_) as its anthem.

#### During World War I[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-
Lorraine&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: During World War I")]

Further information: [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Zabern_Milit%C3%A4rpatrouille.PNG/220px-
Zabern_Milit%C3%A4rpatrouille.PNG)](/wiki/File:Zabern_Milit%C3%A4rpatrouille.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Zabern_Milit%C3%A4rpatrouille.PNG "Enlarge")

German patrol during the Saverne Affair

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Fusill%C3%A9s_de_Gertwiller.jpg/220px-
Fusill%C3%A9s_de_Gertwiller.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fusill%C3%A9s_de_Gertwiller.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Fusill%C3%A9s_de_Gertwiller.jpg "Enlarge")

Translation: _Here at[Gertwiller](/wiki/Gertwiller "Gertwiller") on 22 August
1914 three Alsatian farmers were shot, against all justice. (...) innocent
victims of German barbarity. Alsatians! Remember!_

In French foreign policy, the demand for the return of Alsace and Lorraine
faded in importance after 1880 with the decline of the monarchists element.
When the World War broke out in 1914, recovery of the two lost provinces
became the top French war goal.[8]

In the early 20th century, the increased militarization of Europe, and the
lack of negotiation between major powers, led to harsh and rash actions taken
by both sides in respect to Alsace-Lorraine during [World War
I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"). As soon as war was declared, both the
French and German authorities used the inhabitants of Alsace-Lorraine as
propaganda pawns.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Germans living in France were arrested and placed into camps by the French
authorities. Upon occupying certain villages, veterans of the 1870 conflict
were sought out and arrested by the French army.[9]

The Germans responded to the outbreak of war with harsh measures against the
Alsace-Lorraine populace:[10] the [Saverne Affair](/wiki/Saverne_Affair
"Saverne Affair") had convinced the high command that the population was
hostile to the German Empire and that it should be forced into
submission.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] German troops occupied some homes. The German
military feared French partisans – or _[francs-tireurs](/wiki/Francs-tireurs
"Francs-tireurs")_ , as they had been called during the Franco-Prussian War –
would reappear.

German authorities developed policies aimed at reducing the influence of
French. In Metz, French street names, which had been displayed in French and
German, were suppressed in January 1915. Six months later, on July 15, 1915,
German became the only official language in the region,[11] leading to the
Germanization of the towns’ names effective September 2, 1915.

Prohibiting the speaking of French in public further increased the
exasperation of some of the natives, who were long accustomed to mixing their
conversation with French language (see [code-switching](/wiki/Code-switching
"Code-switching")); however, the use even of one word, as innocent as
"_bonjour_ ", could incur a fine.[note 3] Some ethnic Germans in the region
cooperated in the persecution as a way to demonstrate German patriotism.[note
4]

German authorities became increasingly worried about renewed French
nationalism. The Reichsland governor stated in February 1918: "_Sympathies
towards France and repulsion for Germans have penetrated to a frightening
depth the petty bourgeoisie and the peasantry_ ".[12] But in order to spare
them possible confrontations with relatives in France but also to avoid any
desertion from the Alsatian soldiers to the French army,[note 5][13] German
Army draftees from Alsace-Lorraine were sent mainly to the Eastern front, or
the Navy (_[Kaiserliche Marine](/wiki/Kaiserliche_Marine "Kaiserliche
Marine")_). About 15,000 Alsatians and Lorrainers served in the German Navy.

### Annexation to the French Republic[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-
Lorraine&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Annexation to the French
Republic")]

Main article: [November 1918 in Alsace-
Lorraine](/wiki/November_1918_in_Alsace-Lorraine "November 1918 in Alsace-
Lorraine")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Andr%C3%A9_Bas_et_Marthe_Kuentz_-_1919.jpg/220px-
Andr%C3%A9_Bas_et_Marthe_Kuentz_-_1919.jpg)](/wiki/File:Andr%C3%A9_Bas_et_Marthe_Kuentz_-_1919.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Andr%C3%A9_Bas_et_Marthe_Kuentz_-_1919.jpg "Enlarge")

An Alsatian in traditional dress and a French officer, c. 1919

In the [general revolutionary atmosphere](/wiki/German_Revolution "German
Revolution") of the expiring [German Empire](/wiki/Second_German_Empire
"Second German Empire"), [Marxist](/wiki/Marxist "Marxist") councils of
workers and soldiers _(Soldaten und Arbeiterräte)_ formed in Mulhouse, in
Colmar and Strasbourg in November 1918, in parallel to other such bodies set
up in Germany, in imitation of the Russian equivalent
_[soviets](/wiki/Soviet_\(council\)#Russian_Revolution "Soviet \(council\)")_.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/79/Front_page%2C_Le_Petit_Journal%2C_8_December_1918.jpg/220px-
Front_page%2C_Le_Petit_Journal%2C_8_December_1918.jpg)](/wiki/File:Front_page,_Le_Petit_Journal,_8_December_1918.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Front_page,_Le_Petit_Journal,_8_December_1918.jpg "Enlarge")

_[Metz](/wiki/Metz "Metz") and the Lorraine returned to France_, front page of
_[Le Petit Journal](/wiki/Le_Petit_Journal_\(newspaper\) "Le Petit Journal
\(newspaper\)")_ newspaper dated from 8 December 1918

In this chaotic situation, Alsace-Lorraine's [Landtag](/wiki/Landtag
"Landtag") proclaimed itself the supreme authority of the land with the name
of _Nationalrat_ , the Soviet of Strasbourg claimed the foundation of a
_Republic of Alsace-Lorraine_ , while
[SPD](/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany "Social Democratic Party of
Germany") [Reichstag](/wiki/Reichstag_\(German_Empire\) "Reichstag \(German
Empire\)") representative for Colmar, [Jacques
Peirotes](/wiki/Jacques_Peirotes "Jacques Peirotes"), announced the
establishment of the French rule, urging Paris to send troops quickly.[14]

While the soviet councils disbanded themselves with the departure of the
German troops between November 11 and 17,[15] the arrival of the [French
Army](/wiki/French_Army "French Army") stabilized the situation: French troops
put the region under _[occupatio bellica](/wiki/Military_occupation "Military
occupation")_ and entered Strasbourg on November 21. The Nationalrat
proclaimed the annexation of Alsace to France on December 5, even though this
process did not gain international recognition until the signature of the
[Treaty of Versailles](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles") in
1919.

Alsace-Lorraine was divided into the _[départements](/wiki/D%C3%A9partement
"Département")_ of [Haut-Rhin](/wiki/Haut-Rhin "Haut-Rhin"), [Bas-
Rhin](/wiki/Bas-Rhin "Bas-Rhin") and [Moselle](/wiki/Moselle "Moselle") (the
same political structure as before the annexation and as created by the French
Revolution, with slightly different limits). Today, these territories enjoy
laws that are significantly different from the rest of France – these specific
provisions are known as the [local law](/wiki/Local_law_in_Alsace-Moselle
"Local law in Alsace-Moselle").

The département [Meurthe-et-Moselle](/wiki/Meurthe-et-Moselle "Meurthe-et-
Moselle") was maintained even after France recovered Alsace-Lorraine in 1919.
The area of Belfort became a special status area and was not reintegrated into
[Haut-Rhin](/wiki/Haut-Rhin "Haut-Rhin") in 1919 but instead was made a full-
status département in 1922 under the name [Territoire-de-
Belfort](/wiki/Territoire-de-Belfort "Territoire-de-Belfort").[note 6]

The French Government immediately started a [Francization](/wiki/Francization
"Francization") campaign that included the forced deportation of all Germans
who had settled in the area after 1870. For that purpose, the population was
divided in four categories: A (French citizens before 1870), B (descendants of
such French citizens), C (citizens of Allied or neutral states) and D (enemy
aliens - Germans). By July 1921, 111,915 people categorized as "D" had been
expelled to Germany.[16][17] German-language Alsatian newspapers were also
suppressed.

### World War II[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-
Lorraine&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: World War II")]

Main article: [Malgré-nous](/wiki/Malgr%C3%A9-nous "Malgré-nous")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/ObernaiMalgr%C3%A9Nous.JPG/220px-
ObernaiMalgr%C3%A9Nous.JPG)](/wiki/File:ObernaiMalgr%C3%A9Nous.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:ObernaiMalgr%C3%A9Nous.JPG "Enlarge")

Monument to the Malgré-nous in [Obernai](/wiki/Obernai "Obernai"),
[Alsace](/wiki/Alsace "Alsace")

After the [defeat of France](/wiki/Battle_of_France "Battle of France") in the
spring of 1940, Alsace and Moselle were not formally annexed by [Nazi
Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany"). Although the terms of the
armistice specified that the integrity of the whole French territory could not
be modified in any way, [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler"), the
German [Führer](/wiki/F%C3%BChrer "Führer"), drafted an annexation law in 1940
that he kept secret, expecting to announce it in the event of a German
victory.[18] Through a series of laws which individually seemed minor, Berlin
took full control of Alsace-Lorraine, and Alsatians-Lorrainians could be
drafted into the [German Army](/wiki/German_Army_\(Wehrmacht\) "German Army
\(Wehrmacht\)"). During the occupation, Moselle was integrated into a
[Reichsgau](/wiki/Reichsgau "Reichsgau") named
[Westmark](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Nazi_Germany "Administrative
divisions of Nazi Germany") and Alsace was amalgamated with
[Baden](/wiki/Baden "Baden"). Beginning in 1942, people from Alsace and
Moselle were made German citizens by decree of the [Nazi
government](/wiki/Government_of_Nazi_Germany "Government of Nazi
Germany").[19]

Beginning in October 1942, young Alsatian and Lorrainian men were inducted
into the [German armed forces](/wiki/Wehrmacht "Wehrmacht"). Sometimes they
were known as the _malgré-nous_ , which could be translated in English as
"against our will".[note 7][20][21] A small minority, however, volunteered,
notably the author of _[The Forgotten Soldier](/wiki/The_Forgotten_Soldier
"The Forgotten Soldier")_ , known by the pseudonym [Guy Sajer](/wiki/Guy_Sajer
"Guy Sajer"). Ultimately, 100,000 Alsatians and 30,000 Mosellans were
enrolled, many of them to fight on the [Eastern
Front](/wiki/Eastern_Front_\(World_War_II\) "Eastern Front \(World War II\)")
against the [Soviet Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army"). Most of those who
survived the war were interned in [Tambov](/wiki/Tambov "Tambov") in Russia in
1945. Many others [fought in Normandy](/wiki/Operation_Overlord "Operation
Overlord") against the [Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World
War II") as the _malgré-nous_ of the [2nd SS Panzer Division Das
Reich](/wiki/2nd_SS_Panzer_Division_Das_Reich "2nd SS Panzer Division Das
Reich"), some of which were involved in the [Oradour sur Glane](/wiki/Oradour-
sur-Glane_massacre "Oradour-sur-Glane massacre") and
[Tulle](/wiki/Tulle_massacre "Tulle massacre") war crimes.

Speaking Alsatian, [Lorraine Franconian](/wiki/Lorraine_Franconian "Lorraine
Franconian") or French was prohibited under German occupation, and learning
German was obligatory.

### Religion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-Lorraine&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Religion")]

When Alsace and the [Lorraine department](/wiki/Bezirk_Lothringen "Bezirk
Lothringen") became part of Germany, the French laws regarding religious
bodies were preserved, with special privileges to the then recognised
religions of Calvinism, Judaism, Lutheranism and Roman Catholicism, under a
system known as the [Concordat](/wiki/Concordat_in_Alsace-Moselle "Concordat
in Alsace-Moselle"). However, the [Roman Catholic dioceses of
Metz](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Metz "Roman Catholic Diocese of Metz")
and [of Strasbourg](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Strasbourg "Roman
Catholic Archdiocese of Strasbourg") became
[exempt](/wiki/Exemption_\(church\) "Exemption \(church\)") jurisdictions. The
[Church of Augsburg Confession of
France](/wiki/Evangelical_Lutheran_Church_of_France "Evangelical Lutheran
Church of France")
([fr](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89glise_%C3%A9vang%C3%A9lique_luth%C3%A9rienne_de_France
"fr:Église évangélique luthérienne de France")), with its directory, supreme
consistory and the bulk of its parishioners residing in Alsace, was
reorganised as the [Protestant Church of Augsburg Confession of Alsace and
Lorraine](/wiki/Protestant_Church_of_Augsburg_Confession_of_Alsace_and_Lorraine
"Protestant Church of Augsburg Confession of Alsace and Lorraine") (EPCAAL) in
1872, but territorially reconfined to Alsace-Lorraine only. The five local
Calvinist consistories, originally part of the [Reformed Church of
France](/wiki/Reformed_Church_of_France "Reformed Church of France"), formed a
statewide synod in 1895, the [Protestant Reformed Church of Alsace and
Lorraine](/wiki/Reformed_Church_of_Alsace_and_Lorraine "Reformed Church of
Alsace and Lorraine") (EPRAL). The three [Israelite
consistories](/wiki/Consistory_\(Judaism\) "Consistory \(Judaism\)") in
[Colmar](/w/index.php?title=Colmar_Consistory&action=edit&redlink=1 "Colmar
Consistory \(page does not exist\)")
([de](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consistoire_Colmar "de:Consistoire
Colmar")), [Metz](/w/index.php?title=Metz_Consistory&action=edit&redlink=1
"Metz Consistory \(page does not exist\)")
([de](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consistoire_Metz "de:Consistoire Metz"))
and
[Strasbourg](/w/index.php?title=Strasbourg_Consistory&action=edit&redlink=1
"Strasbourg Consistory \(page does not exist\)")
([de](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consistoire_Stra%C3%9Fburg "de:Consistoire
Straßburg")) were disentangled from supervision by the [Israelite Central
Consistory of France](/wiki/Central_Consistory "Central Consistory") and
continued as separate [statutory corporations](/wiki/Statutory_corporation
"Statutory corporation") which never formed a joint body, but cooperated. All
the mentioned religious bodies retained the status as _établissements publics
de culte_ (public bodies of [Religion](/wiki/Religion "Religion")). When the
new Alsace-Lorraine constitution of 1911 provided for a
[bicameral](/wiki/Bicameralism "Bicameralism") state parliament ([Landtag of
Alsace-Lorraine](/w/index.php?title=Landtag_of_Alsace-
Lorraine&action=edit&redlink=1 "Landtag of Alsace-Lorraine \(page does not
exist\)") ([fr](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landtag_d%27Alsace-Lorraine
"fr:Landtag d'Alsace-Lorraine"))) each recognised religion was entitled to
send a representative into the first chamber of the Landtag as [ex
officio](/wiki/Ex_officio "Ex officio") members (the [bishops of
Strasbourg](/wiki/Bishop_of_Strasbourg "Bishop of Strasbourg") and of Metz,
the presidents of EPCAAL and EPRAL, and a delegate of the three Israelite
consistories).

#### Religious statistics in 1910[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-
Lorraine&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Religious statistics in 1910")]

Population 1,874,014 :[22]

  * Catholic: 76.22%
  * Protestant: 21.78% (18.87% Lutherans, 2.91% Calvinists)
  * Jewish: 1.63%
  * Other Christian: 0.21%
  * Atheist: 0.12%

### Statistics (1866–2010)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-
Lorraine&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Statistics \(1866–2010\)")]

Year | Population | Cause of change  
---|---|---  
1866 | 1,596,198 | –  
1875 | 1,531,804 | After incorporation into the [German Empire](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire"), 100,000 to 130,000 people left for France and French Algeria  
1910 | 1,874,014 | +0.58% population growth per year during 1875-1910  
1921 | 1,709,749 | Death of young men in the German army (1914–18);  
Deportation of persons considered German by the French authorities.  
1936 | 1,915,627 | +0.76% population growth per year during 1921–1936  
1946 | 1,767,131 | Death of young men in the French army in 1939–45,  
Death of young men in the German army in 1942–45,  
Death of civilians and many people still refugees in the rest of France  
1975 | 2,523,703 | +1.24% population growth per year during 1946–1975, a period of rapid population and economic growth in France known as the [Trente Glorieuses](/wiki/Trente_Glorieuses "Trente Glorieuses")  
2010 | 2,890,753 | +0.39% population growth per year during 1975–2010, a period marked by [deindustrialization](/wiki/Deindustrialization "Deindustrialization"), rising unemployment (particularly in Moselle), and the migration of many people from northern and north-eastern France to the milder winters and economic dynamism of the Mediterranean and Atlantic regions of France  
  
### Languages[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Alsace-Lorraine&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Languages")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Alsace-
Lorraine_Dialects.png/310px-Alsace-Lorraine_Dialects.png)](/wiki/File:Alsace-
Lorraine_Dialects.png)

[](/wiki/File:Alsace-Lorraine_Dialects.png "Enlarge")

Spatial distribution of dialects in Alsace-Lorraine before the expansion of
[standard French](/wiki/Standard_French "Standard French") in the 20th century

Both [Germanic](/wiki/Germanic_languages "Germanic languages") and
[Romance](/wiki/Romance_languages "Romance languages") dialects were
traditionally spoken in Alsace-Lorraine before the 20th century.

Germanic dialects:

  * [Central German](/wiki/Central_German "Central German") dialects: 
    * [Luxembourgish Franconian](/wiki/Luxembourgish_language "Luxembourgish language") aka Luxembourgish in the north-west of [Moselle](/wiki/Moselle "Moselle") (_Lothringen_) around [Thionville](/wiki/Thionville "Thionville") (_Diddenuewen_ in the local Luxembourgish dialect) and [Sierck-les-Bains](/wiki/Sierck-les-Bains "Sierck-les-Bains") (_Siirk_ in the local Luxembourgish dialect).
    * [Moselle Franconian](/wiki/Moselle_Franconian "Moselle Franconian") in the central northern part of Moselle around [Boulay-Moselle](/wiki/Boulay-Moselle "Boulay-Moselle") (_Bolchin_ in the local Moselle Franconian dialect) and [Bouzonville](/wiki/Bouzonville "Bouzonville") (_Busendroff_ in the local Moselle Franconian dialect).
    * [Rhine Franconian](/wiki/Rhine_Franconian "Rhine Franconian") in the north-east of Moselle around [Forbach](/wiki/Forbach "Forbach") (_Fuerboch_ in the local Rhine Franconian dialect), [Bitche](/wiki/Bitche "Bitche") (_Bitsch_ in the local Rhine Franconian dialect), and [Sarrebourg](/wiki/Sarrebourg "Sarrebourg") (_Saarbuerj_ in the local Rhine Franconian dialect), as well as in the north-west of [Alsace](/wiki/Alsace "Alsace") around [Sarre-Union](/wiki/Sarre-Union "Sarre-Union") (_Buckenum_ in the local Rhine Franconian dialect) and [La Petite-Pierre](/wiki/La_Petite-Pierre "La Petite-Pierre") (_Lítzelstain_ in the local Rhine Franconian dialect).
  * Transitional between Central German and Upper German: 
    * [South Franconian](/wiki/South_Franconian "South Franconian") in the northernmost part of Alsace around [Wissembourg](/wiki/Wissembourg "Wissembourg") (_Waisseburch_ in the local South Franconian dialect).
  * [Upper German](/wiki/Upper_German "Upper German") dialects: 
    * [Alsatian](/wiki/Alsatian_language "Alsatian language") in the largest part of Alsace and in a few villages around [Phalsbourg](/wiki/Phalsbourg "Phalsbourg") in the extreme south-east of Moselle. Alsatian was the most spoken dialect in Alsace-Lorraine.
    * [High Alemannic](/wiki/High_Alemannic "High Alemannic") in the southernmost part of Alsace, around [Saint-Louis](/wiki/Saint-Louis,_Haut-Rhin "Saint-Louis, Haut-Rhin") and [Ferrette](/wiki/Ferrette "Ferrette") (_Pfirt_ in the local High Alemannic dialect).

Romance dialects (belonging to the [langues d'oïl](/wiki/Langues_d%27o%C3%AFl
"Langues d'oïl") like French):

  * [Lorrain](/wiki/Lorrain_language "Lorrain language") in roughly the southern half of Moselle, including its capital [Metz](/wiki/Metz "Metz"), as well as in some valleys of the [Vosges Mountains](/wiki/Vosges_Mountains "Vosges Mountains") in the west of Alsace around [Schirmeck](/wiki/Schirmeck "Schirmeck") and [Sainte-Marie-aux-Mines](/wiki/Sainte-Marie-aux-Mines "Sainte-Marie-aux-Mines").
  * [Franc-Comtois](/wiki/Frainc-Comtou_dialect "Frainc-Comtou dialect") in 12 villages in the extreme south-west of Alsace.

"Edit section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** An instruction dated 1920-08-14 from the assistant Secretary of State of the Presidency of the Council to the General Commissioner of the Republic in Strasbourg reminds that the term _Alsace-Lorraine_ is prohibited and must be replaced by the sentence "the [département](/wiki/D%C3%A9partement_of_France "Département of France") of [Haut-Rhin](/wiki/Haut-Rhin "Haut-Rhin"), the département of [Bas-Rhin](/wiki/Bas-Rhin "Bas-Rhin") and the département of [Moselle](/wiki/Moselle "Moselle")". While this sentence was considered as too long, some used the term _Alsace-Moselle_ to point to the three concerned départements. However, this instruction has no legal status because it is not based on any territorial authority.
  2. **Jump up ^** The linguistic border ran on the north of the new border, including in the "Alemannic" territories [Thionville](/wiki/Thionville "Thionville") (also named _[Diedenhofen](/wiki/Diedenhofen "Diedenhofen")_ under the German Reich), [Metz](/wiki/Metz "Metz"), [Château-Salins](/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau-Salins "Château-Salins"), [Vic-sur-Seille](/wiki/Vic-sur-Seille "Vic-sur-Seille") and [Dieuze](/wiki/Dieuze "Dieuze"), which were fully French-speaking. The valleys of [Orbey](/wiki/Orbey "Orbey") and [Sainte-Marie-aux-Mines](/wiki/Sainte-Marie-aux-Mines "Sainte-Marie-aux-Mines") were in the same case. Similarly, the town of Dannemarie (and adjoining areas) were also left in [Alsace](/wiki/Alsace "Alsace") when language alone could have made them part of [Territoire de Belfort](/wiki/Territoire_de_Belfort "Territoire de Belfort").
  3. **Jump up ^** As of on October 26, 1914, we can read in Spindler's journal: "Then he recommends to me not to speak French. The streets are infested with informers, men and women, who touch rewards and make arrest the passers by for a simple « merci » said in French. It goes without saying that these measures excite the joker spirit of the people. A woman at the market, who probably was unaware that "_bonchour_ " and "_merci_ " was French, is taken with part by a German woman because she answered her "_Guten Tag_ " by a "_bonchour_ ". Then, the good woman, the fists on the hips, challenges her client : "Now I'm fed up with your silly stories! Do you know what? [here something like "_kiss my ..._ "]! Is that endly also French? » (als: Jetz grad genua mit dene dauwe Plän! Wisse Sie was? Leeke Sie mich ...! Esch des am End au franzêsch?)"
  4. **Jump up ^** We can read in _L 'Alsace pendant la guerre_ how the exasperation of the population gradually increased but Spindler hears on September 29, 1914, a characteristic sentence: « ... the interior decorator H., who repairs the mattresses of the Ott house, said to me this morning: “If only it was the will of God that we became again French and that these damned "_Schwowebittel_ " were thrown out of the country! And then, you know, there are chances that it happens.” It is the first time since the war I hear a simple man expressing frankly this wish. »
  5. **Jump up ^** One of the famous case was the desertion from all the Alsatian soldiers from their German bataillion the eve of the Verdun offensive to warn the French army from the imminent attack
